title: 103_hr654
content: The "United States Mint Bicentennial Coin Act" specifies the minting of five dollar gold coins, one dollar silver coins, and half dollar silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The Act limits the number of coins to be minted for each denomination. The Secretary will obtain gold for coins from existing law and silver from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the five dollar gold coins features Alexander Hamilton on the obverse and the inspection of the first US coins on the reverse. The one dollar silver coins portray Thomas Jefferson on the obverse and the first coining press on the reverse. The half dollar silver coins have a different design. The design of the half dollar silver coins depicts David Rittenhouse on the obverse and the first mint building on the reverse. Each coin also includes inscriptions of "United States of America", "E Pluribus Unum", "In God We Trust", and "Liberty". The design of the half dollar silver coins depicts David Rittenhouse on the obverse and the first mint building on the reverse, with inscriptions of "United States of America", "E Pluribus Unum", "In God We Trust", and "Liberty". SEC. 5. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing them. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and a surcharge will be added to each coin. The Secretary must report sales to Congress monthly. Each report submitted must review all marketing activities and provide a financial statement detailing sources of funds, surcharges generated, and expenses incurred. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS. The coins authorized under this Act shall be minted and available for issue no later than July 15, 1993, but shall be issued only during 1993. The coins shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the Bureau of the Mint used to strike any particular combination of denomination and quality. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods or services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to the Smithsonian for the National Numismatic Collection. Funds are used for purchasing materials, promoting study, and renovating exhibit facilities. SEC. 9. The Comptroller General can audit the organizing committee's financial records related to section 208 expenditures. SEC. 10. Financial assurances are required. SEC. 10. Financial assurances are necessary to ensure no net cost to the Federal Government for minting and issuing coins under section 202. Payment must be received in full, or security or guarantee provided to indemnify the United States.
